At 7:40 you explain that one of the two plastid membranes comes from the host cell. But the original endosymbiont already had a double membrane in the first place. It would seem that the membrane of the vacuole which engulfed the endosymbiot was lost, and the two remaining membranes are the original ones that the cyanobacterium already had. See here for example:  Keeling PJ (October 2004). "Diversity and evolutionary history of plastids and their hosts". American Journal of Botany.

Not a lie, it's a scientific theory that you're choosing not to believe for reasons which are valid.

It is a lie, because biological evolution in the way they describe it cannot happen. A fish cannot turn into a human. Mutations prove this by showing that there has never been a mutation that has added new additional genetic information to an organisms genetic code producing new genomes. In order for evolution to take place there needs to be, at some point, the addition of new genetic information to an organisms Genetic Code. Since mutations only swap or negate existing information, this results in a loss of functional systems. If evolution were true we would need to see a gain of functional systems not a loss. a fish would need more additional new genetic information to produce and evlove a leg. But mutations cannot do this. So the basis for biological evolution is purposely flawed, yet still promoted as truth. This shows evolution as a deliberate lie.

Actually... Humans can digest some cellulose because we still have a cecum at the end of our small intestine (structure that houses cellulose digesting bacteria). Am I the only one annoyed that he says glucose not beta glucose, beta glucose chain carbohydrates are the reason cellulose is so rigid, because beta glucose has to flip for the OH and HO to form a glycocidic bond. If it was an alpha glucose chain carbohydrate it would be starch (or amylose) and would have a coiled structure. I don't know if it is just the biology level this is aimed towards but carbohydrates aren't very high level so I'm curious. Either way I still love these videos as refreshers of topics :)

Hi, I also have a few questions,... first Mitochondria (or rather their DNA) in human cells can be used to find this one Eve, but I wonder how much does the Mitochondrial DNA in animals differ from ours? And why does the mitochandrial DNA not change with time? We observe mutations in the DNA of rhe nucelous all the time - this is what makes us different - so why doesn't the mitochondrial DNA change? Also I wonder if there is something like Mitochondrial-cancer, you know cancer cells divide and divide and grow. Couldn't a mitochondria do the same? So back to the plants, what brought me to that questions the first time. If chloroplasts are like mitochondria, swallowed up bacteria, and if we can use the mitochondrial DNA in Mitochondria to find Eve for humans, can't we than use the DNA in chloroplast to find plant-Eve. And also if plants also have Mitochondria and and also their cells are eucaryotic couldn't it be that there was one cell in the beginning that did catch a mitochondria and kept it and then divided, and one of those then did catch the cytoplast? What I'm getting to is couldn't we use the DNA in those litte organells to find the common ancestor (cell) of plants and animals? And thanks for being awesome! :-)

I had the same question, and if anyone sees this in the future: edible (digestible!) plants have less cellulose and more nutrients. Think of it as a scale; the less cellulose a plant has the easier you'll get on with eating it ((on principle, obviously it's not a good idea to eat anything just because it doesn't consist mostly of cellulose))

OMG! Sorry about being a science newb here, but you said a thing near the beginning of the video that blew my mind. The idea that flowering plants might have killed the dinosaurs. Flowering plants have that pollen stuff, which cause "allergies" in some people (and probably animals) and dinosaurs, probably not having to deal with something like that before (besides say, stray dead skin particles in the air and whatever else passed for dust back then) wouldn't physically know how to deal with them. Maybe. I don't know, but the idea excited me and I got all science giddy, which I thank you for.

Vesicles are made from the golgi apparatus containing particles to be sent across, into, or out of the cell. Vacuoles are organelles containing water and waste products that provide support for plant cells. Plastids are plant organelles containing compounds for photosynthesis.
